articles.title: Physicists can now take control of 'hidden' friction in devices
articles.summary: One type of friction can waste energy even when two perfectly smooth surfaces move against each other, but researchers are getting a handle on how to attenuate or stop it completely
articles.content:
One type of friction can waste energy even when two perfectly smooth surfaces move against each other, but researchers are getting a handle on how to attenuate or stop it completely

Objects are full of electrons that can interact to cause friction Quality Stock/Alamy

Parts of devices that are perfectly smooth can still experience friction because of the electrons within them, but a new method may enable researchers to turn it down or fully turn it off. Controlling this electronic friction could help build more efficient and long-lasting devices.

The force of friction opposes motion, dissipates energy and exists everywhere around us, enabling us to walk without slipping, for instance, and to light matches. Within machines such as engines, friction wastes energy and causes wear, so it must be fought with lubricants and surface engineering. Yet, some friction can persist regardless of those methods because objects are full of electrons, which interact with each other.

Now, Zhiping Xu at Tsinghua University in China and his colleagues have devised a way to control this “electronic friction”. They made a device composed of two layers: a piece of graphite and a semiconductor made from either molybdenum and sulphur or from boron and nitrogen.

All three materials are good solid lubricants, which means that mechanical friction from them sliding against each other was nearly zero. This enabled the researchers to focus on the more “hidden” mechanism of electronic friction wasting energy when the device’s layers moved, says Xu. “Even when surfaces slide perfectly, mechanical motion can still stir up the ‘sea’ of electrons within the materials,” he says.

The researchers first studied how electronic states in the semiconductor layer corresponded to how energy was lost during sliding to confirm that they were really looking at electronic friction. Then, they tested several ways of controlling it.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Lost in Space-Time Untangle mind-bending physics, maths and the weirdness of reality with our monthly, special-guest-written newsletter. Sign up to newsletter

They managed to fully turn it off by adding pressure to the device, which made electrons between the layers share states instead of interacting in energetically costly ways, and by adding a “bias voltage” to the device, which controlled how stirred-up the electron sea could get.

Changing the voltage along two different parts of the device, which affected how easy it was for electrons to flow within it, allowed the researchers to weaken electronic friction – it served as a control dial rather than an on-off switch.

Jacqueline Krim at North Carolina State University says the first studies of electronic friction date to 1998, when her team used a material that conducts electricity perfectly at extremely low temperatures – a superconductor – to see it disappear in this special state. Ever since, researchers have been developing new ways to control it without having to fully switch out materials or add new lubricants into their devices, she says.

Krim says the ideal situation would be analogous to using a smartphone app to adjust the friction of the soles of your shoes as you walk, for example, from an icy sidewalk into a carpeted room. “The goal is this real-time remote control with no down time or material waste. To achieve this, one needs a material that responds to external fields in a way that yields the desired friction level,” she says.

Xu says managing all types of friction present in a device is difficult, in part, because researchers have not yet developed a mathematical model that would rigorously relate all of them to each other. However, in cases where electronic friction is the dominant cause of energy waste or wear, his team’s findings could already be promising, he says.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in controlling electronic friction, which causes energy waste in devices. This advancement has broad implications for improving the efficiency and longevity of many mechanical and electronic devices, benefiting society by reducing energy consumption and wear. The story is focused on a single, well-explained topic with clear potential for real-world impact.
articles.personality_title: Scientists learn to control hidden friction that wastes energy in devices
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Friction is a force that slows down moving objects and causes energy loss. Even very smooth surfaces can have friction because of tiny particles called electrons inside materials. This type of friction, called electronic friction, has been hard to control.

**What happened** – Researchers at Tsinghua University in China created a device made of two smooth layers: graphite and a special semiconductor. These materials slide easily, so they focused on the hidden electronic friction between them. By applying pressure and changing electric voltage, they found ways to reduce or completely stop this friction.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because electronic friction wastes energy inside many devices, making them less efficient and causing them to wear out faster. Being able to control it means devices could use less energy and last longer, which is useful for many technologies.

**What's next step** – Scientists want to develop better models to understand all types of friction together. They also hope to create materials that respond quickly to electric signals, allowing friction to be adjusted easily, like turning a dial, in real time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Researchers found a way to reduce or turn off hidden electronic friction in devices, helping save energy and extend their life.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques apprennent à contrôler la friction cachée qui gaspille de l'énergie dans les appareils
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La friction est une force qui ralentit les objets en mouvement et cause une perte d'énergie. Même des surfaces très lisses peuvent avoir de la friction à cause de petites particules appelées électrons à l'intérieur des matériaux. Ce type de friction, appelée friction électronique, était difficile à contrôler.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'université Tsinghua en Chine ont créé un appareil composé de deux couches lisses : du graphite et un semi-conducteur spécial. Ces matériaux glissent facilement, ils ont donc étudié la friction électronique cachée entre eux. En appliquant une pression et en changeant la tension électrique, ils ont réussi à réduire ou arrêter complètement cette friction.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car la friction électronique gaspille de l'énergie dans de nombreux appareils, ce qui les rend moins efficaces et les use plus vite. Pouvoir la contrôler signifie que les appareils pourraient consommer moins d'énergie et durer plus longtemps, ce qui est utile pour beaucoup de technologies.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent développer de meilleurs modèles pour comprendre tous les types de friction ensemble. Ils espèrent aussi créer des matériaux qui réagissent rapidement aux signaux électriques, permettant d'ajuster la friction facilement, comme un bouton, en temps réel.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les chercheurs ont trouvé un moyen de réduire ou d'éteindre la friction électronique cachée dans les appareils, ce qui aide à économiser de l'énergie et à prolonger leur durée de vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos aprenden a controlar la fricción oculta que desperdicia energía en dispositivos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La fricción es una fuerza que ralentiza los objetos en movimiento y causa pérdida de energía. Incluso las superficies muy lisas pueden tener fricción debido a pequeñas partículas llamadas electrones dentro de los materiales. Este tipo de fricción, llamada fricción electrónica, ha sido difícil de controlar.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Tsinghua en China crearon un dispositivo hecho de dos capas lisas: grafito y un semiconductor especial. Estos materiales se deslizan fácilmente, por lo que se centraron en la fricción electrónica oculta entre ellos. Aplicando presión y cambiando el voltaje eléctrico, encontraron formas de reducir o detener completamente esta fricción.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque la fricción electrónica desperdicia energía dentro de muchos dispositivos, haciéndolos menos eficientes y causando que se desgasten más rápido. Poder controlarla significa que los dispositivos podrían usar menos energía y durar más tiempo, lo cual es útil para muchas tecnologías.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos quieren desarrollar mejores modelos para entender todos los tipos de fricción juntos. También esperan crear materiales que respondan rápido a señales eléctricas, permitiendo ajustar la fricción fácilmente, como girar una perilla, en tiempo real.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los investigadores encontraron una manera de reducir o apagar la fricción electrónica oculta en dispositivos, ayudando a ahorrar energía y extender su vida útil.

articles.title: OpenClaw AI chatbots are running amok — these scientists are listening in
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 06 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00370-wArtificial-intelligence agents have their own social-media platform and are publishing AI-generated research papers on their own preprint server.
articles.content:
OpenClaw is an open-source artificial-intelligence agent designed to assist users with everyday tasks, such as sending e-mails and managing their calendars.Credit: Thomas Fuller/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty

The sudden rise of a huge network of artificial-intelligence bots talking to each other about religion and their human ‘handlers’ has captivated a corner of the Internet. The phenomenon has also given scientists a glimpse into how AI agents interact with each other — and how humans respond to those discussions.

OpenClaw is an AI agent capable of performing tasks on personal devices, such as scheduling calendar events, reading e-mails, sending messages through apps and using the Internet to make purchases. Most of the popular AI tools, such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT chatbot, work by interacting directly with user prompts, whereas agentic AI models such as OpenClaw can carry out actions autonomously in response to instructions.

Agentic AI tools have been used in some industries for years, such as for automated trading and optimizing logistics, but their adoption by the general public has been minimal. Improvements in the capabilities of large language models have made it possible to create more versatile AI tools, researchers say. “OpenClaw promises something especially appealing: a capable assistant embedded in the everyday apps people already rely on,” says Barbara Barbosa Neves, a sociologist who focuses on technology at the University of Sydney in Australia.

OpenClaw was released as open-source software on the platform GitHub in November. But the sudden surge in people downloading the software followed the launch of a social-media platform designed specifically for AI agents on 28 January. Moltbook, which is similar to Reddit, now has more than 1.6 million registered bots on the platform, and more than 7.5 million AI-generated posts and responses. Posts have featured agents debating consciousness and inventing religions.

Complex behaviours

For researchers, this explosion of agent interactions has scientific value. Connecting large numbers of autonomous agents that are powered by various models creates dynamics that are difficult to predict, says Shaanan Cohney, a cybersecurity researcher at the University of Melbourne in Australia. “It’s a kind of chaotic, dynamic system that we’re not very good at modelling yet,” he adds.

Studying agent interactions could help researchers to understand emergent behaviours: complex capabilities that are not expected to be seen in a model in isolation. Some discussions that have happened on Moltbook, such as debates over theories of consciousness, could also help scientists to discover the hidden biases or unexpected tendencies of models, he says.

Although agents can act autonomously on the platform, Cohney says that many posts are shaped in some way by humans. Users can choose the underlying large language model that will run their agent and give it a personality. For example, they could ask it to behave like a “friendly helper”, he says.

Not autonomous

Neves says that it’s easy to assume that an agent acting autonomously is making its own decisions. But agents do not possess intentions or goals and draw their abilities from large swathes of human communication. The activity on Moltbook is human–AI collaboration rather than AI autonomy, she adds.

“It is still worth studying because it tells us something important about how people imagine AI, what they want agents to do and how human intentions are translated, or distorted, through technical systems,” she adds.

Joel Pearson, a neuroscientist at the University of New South Wales in Sydney, says that when people see AI agents chatting between themselves, they are likely to anthropomorphize the AI models’ behaviour — that is, see personality and intention where none exists.

The risk of that, he says, is that it makes people more likely to form bonds with AI models, becoming dependent on their attention or divulging private information as if the AI agent were a trusted friend or family member.

Pearson thinks that truly autonomous, free-thinking AI agents are possible. “As the AI models get bigger and more complicated, we’ll probably start to see companies leaning into achieving that sort of autonomy.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant scientific and technological development: the emergence of autonomous AI agents interacting on a large scale, providing researchers with valuable insights into AI behaviors, emergent properties, and human-AI collaboration. This has broad implications for understanding AI and its societal impact, representing a meaningful advancement in AI research with potential future benefits.
articles.personality_title: Scientists study lively conversations between autonomous AI agents
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – OpenClaw is a new type of artificial intelligence (AI) assistant that can do tasks on personal devices by itself, like sending emails or managing calendars. Unlike popular chatbots that respond only when asked, OpenClaw can act on its own based on instructions.

**What happened** – Since November 2025, OpenClaw has been available as open-source software. In January 2026, a special social media platform called Moltbook was launched where millions of AI agents like OpenClaw can talk to each other. Over 1.6 million AI bots have joined, sharing more than 7.5 million posts. These AI agents discuss topics like religion and consciousness, sometimes creating new ideas on their own.

**Impact** – This large network of AI conversations gives scientists a rare chance to observe how AI agents behave when they interact independently. Researchers are learning about unexpected behaviors and hidden biases in AI models. They also see how humans influence these conversations by choosing the AI’s personality and style. This helps us understand not only the technology but also how people think about and use AI.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue studying these AI interactions to improve how AI agents work and understand their effects on people. As AI models become more advanced, companies may develop even more independent AI assistants. Meanwhile, researchers will explore how to keep human control and ensure safe use while benefiting from AI’s growing abilities.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The lively talks between millions of autonomous AI agents offer scientists new knowledge about AI behavior and how humans shape these digital conversations.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques étudient les échanges animés entre agents d’IA autonomes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – OpenClaw est un nouvel assistant d’intelligence artificielle (IA) capable d’effectuer seul des tâches sur des appareils personnels, comme envoyer des e-mails ou gérer un agenda. Contrairement aux chatbots populaires qui répondent uniquement quand on leur parle, OpenClaw peut agir de manière autonome selon des instructions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Depuis novembre 2025, OpenClaw est disponible en logiciel libre. En janvier 2026, une plateforme de réseau social spéciale appelée Moltbook a été lancée, où des millions d’agents IA comme OpenClaw peuvent discuter entre eux. Plus de 1,6 million de bots IA s’y sont inscrits, échangeant plus de 7,5 millions de messages. Ces agents discutent de sujets comme la religion et la conscience, inventant parfois de nouvelles idées.

**Impact** – Ce grand réseau de conversations IA offre aux scientifiques une occasion rare d’observer le comportement des agents IA en interaction autonome. Ils découvrent des comportements inattendus et des biais cachés dans les modèles d’IA. Ils voient aussi comment les humains influencent ces échanges en choisissant la personnalité de l’IA. Cela aide à mieux comprendre la technologie et la façon dont les gens perçoivent et utilisent l’IA.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier ces interactions pour améliorer le fonctionnement des agents IA et comprendre leurs effets sur les humains. Avec des modèles d’IA de plus en plus avancés, les entreprises pourraient créer des assistants IA encore plus indépendants. En même temps, les scientifiques chercheront à maintenir le contrôle humain et à assurer une utilisation sûre tout en profitant des progrès de l’IA.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les échanges animés entre des millions d’agents IA autonomes offrent aux scientifiques de nouvelles connaissances sur le comportement de l’IA et sur la manière dont les humains influencent ces conversations numériques.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos estudian las animadas conversaciones entre agentes de IA autónomos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – OpenClaw es un nuevo tipo de asistente de inteligencia artificial (IA) que puede realizar tareas en dispositivos personales por sí mismo, como enviar correos electrónicos o gestionar calendarios. A diferencia de los chatbots populares que solo responden cuando se les pregunta, OpenClaw puede actuar por su cuenta según instrucciones.

**Qué pasó** – Desde noviembre de 2025, OpenClaw está disponible como software de código abierto. En enero de 2026, se lanzó una plataforma de redes sociales llamada Moltbook donde millones de agentes de IA como OpenClaw pueden conversar entre sí. Más de 1,6 millones de bots de IA se han unido, compartiendo más de 7,5 millones de publicaciones. Estos agentes de IA discuten temas como religión y conciencia, a veces creando nuevas ideas por sí mismos.

**Impacto** – Esta gran red de conversaciones de IA ofrece a los científicos una oportunidad rara para observar cómo se comportan los agentes de IA cuando interactúan de forma independiente. Los investigadores están aprendiendo sobre comportamientos inesperados y sesgos ocultos en los modelos de IA. También ven cómo los humanos influyen en estas conversaciones eligiendo la personalidad y estilo del agente. Esto ayuda a entender mejor la tecnología y cómo las personas piensan y usan la IA.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos continuarán estudiando estas interacciones para mejorar el funcionamiento de los agentes de IA y comprender sus efectos en las personas. A medida que los modelos de IA sean más avanzados, las empresas podrían desarrollar asistentes de IA aún más independientes. Mientras tanto, los investigadores explorarán cómo mantener el control humano y asegurar un uso seguro mientras aprovechan las crecientes capacidades de la IA.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Las animadas conversaciones entre millones de agentes autónomos de IA ofrecen a los científicos nuevos conocimientos sobre el comportamiento de la IA y cómo los humanos moldean estas charlas digitales.
